channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Egypt Has Reportedly Banned ‘Exodus: Gods and Kings’ Movie
item.description: If confirmed, Egypt would be the second Arab country to ban the $140 million film, which depicts the biblical flight of the Jews from Egypt.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Tensions in Sweden After 5 Are Injured in Fire at Mosque
item.description: Officials feared hate crimes were on the rise after a suspicious fire in Sweden, a country known for welcoming immigrants that now has a right-wing element.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: People left flowers, teddy bears and other mementos outside a mosque in Eskilstuna, Sweden, on Friday, a day after a suspicious fire there.

item.title: Lens Blog: American Culture, Riding a Mushroom Cloud
item.description: In “Chewing Gum and Chocolate,” Shomei Tomatsu explored the attractions and contradictions of American culture and the military in postwar Japan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MAURICE BERGER

item.title: Irish Court Rules Brain-Dead Pregnant Woman May Be Taken Off Life Support
item.description: Doctors can turn off life support to a clinically dead pregnant woman, judges ruled, in the case of a brain-dead woman in Dublin whose fetus has little chance of surviving.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Camel Racing Blends Centuries-Old Traditions and Modern Technology
item.description: Camel racing has been part of Arabian culture for generations, but the widespread use of robots as jockeys is giving the sport a modern twist.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The robots, which are made to look like tiny jockeys, weigh only a few pounds each.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Hit Back Against a Foreign Intrusion: Christmas
item.description: As some Chinese enjoy the trappings of Western-style Christmas, and retailers enjoy some of their highest sales in late December, others are calling for bans on any celebrations.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Students in Changsha, Hunan Province, on Wednesday displayed banners reading "Resist Christmas. Chinese should not celebrate foreign festivals."

item.title: Kiev and Separatists Swap Prisoners as Peace Talks Break Down
item.description: The prisoner exchange came as peace talks between Russia and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe came to a halt in Belarus.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: DealBook: Scaled-Up Banking Rescue to Push Russian Budget Into Deficit
item.description: Russia’s central bank said its bailout of Trust Bank – the first major lender to fail as a result of the sharp decline in the ruble – would cost about $2.5 billion, far more than previously anticipated.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A Trust Bank branch in Moscow displays an ad featuring Bruce Willis.

item.title: SÃo LuÍs Journal: Decline of a Political Family Opens the Way for a Shift in Brazil
item.description: As José Sarney leaves Brazil’s Senate, his family dynasty in Maranhão State is showing signs of strain.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bust of José Sarney, a senator and former president of Brazil, at the Convento das Mercês. Mr. Sarney's name and image are ubiquitous in São Luís, the capital of Maranhão State.

item.title: China’s Leadership Praises Hong Kong’s Top Official
item.description: Comments by President Xi Jinping and others were a public reminder that Leung Chun-ying, the city’s chief executive, has Beijing’s backing.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: How a Syrian Boy, 14 and Sheathed in Explosives, Escaped ISIS’ Hold
item.description: Usaid Barho, a Syrian youth who gave himself up rather than bomb a Shiite mosque, is one of thousands of children recruited by the militant group Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: 2 Drone Strikes in Pakistan Are Said to Kill 9 Militant Suspects
item.description: The strikes in the northwest were believed to have been carried out by American aircraft, a Pakistani security official said.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Viewers Mostly Give Thumbs Up for ‘The Interview’
item.description: By midday on Friday, more than 300,000 people in China had seen the film about a plot to assassinate Kim Jong-un of North Korea and the reviews, by and large, were favorable.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: "The Interview" portrays a C.I.A. plot to assassinate the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, played by the actor Randall Park.

item.title: Palestinian Wounds 2 Israeli Police Officers in Jerusalem
item.description: The assailant approached the officers after dawn prayers at Al Aqsa Mosque, stabbed one in the neck and injured the other in the ensuing struggle, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Jill Robinson on Animals and Empathy in Asia
item.description: Ms. Robinson discusses Animals Asia Foundation’s work to end bear bile farming in China and Vietnam, changing cultural attitudes in Asia and the bear that reached out to her.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Jill Robinson, founder of the Animals Asia Foundation.

item.title: Loss by Taiwan’s Governing Party Raises Fears That Ties With China Will Sour
item.description: When the opposition Democratic Progressive Party last held power, it presided over a period of increased tensions with the mainland.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Saudi Antiterrorism Court to Try Women Held for Driving
item.description: Two Saudi women detained for nearly a month after they defied edicts that prohibit women from driving were referred on Thursday to a court established to try terrorism cases.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Set to Cut Force in Darfur as Fighting Rises
item.description: United Nations officials say their forces are routinely attacked by Sudanese forces and their proxies and that it is virtually impossible for their peacekeepers to remain without Sudan’s blessing.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Women and children in North Darfur, where Sudanese soldiers were accused of mass rape. Human rights groups say that peacekeepers botched an investigation into the matter.

item.title: For Sri Lankan President, Renounced by Aides, Confidence of Re-election Dims
item.description: Defectors from the cabinet of President Mahinda Rajapaksa have bragged about plotting their desertion under his nose.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: President Mahinda Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka, center front, has set elections for Jan. 8, two years before the end of his second term.

item.title: Death Sentence in Mauritania for Islam ‘Insult’
item.description: The man, Mohamed Cheikh Ould Mkhaitir, 28, was arrested a year ago for writing an article that was interpreted by some as being critical of the Prophet Muhammad.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
